awd_titl_txt: Conference: Geometric and Asymptotic Group Theory with Applications 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for the U.S.-based participants of the conference “Geometric and Asymptotic Group Theory with Applications 2023” that will take place July 17-21 at the Erwin Schroedinger Institute, Vienna, Austria. The conference is organized by the PI Kim Ruane in collaboration with Christopher Cashen (University of Vienna), Sangyun Kim (Korea Advanced Institute of Science & Technology), and Yash Lodha (University of Hawaii). This is the 16th edition of an annual series, previous iterations of which have been held in ten different countries on four continents. The goal of the conference is to bring together both early career and established researchers in combinatorial, asymptotic, and geometric aspects of infinite group theory together with researchers in dynamics and discrete probability, to consolidate recent advances based on the interplay between these subjects and to spark new interactions. The conference will feature plenary talks and a discussion session of open problems. Organizers plan a targeted recruitment process to broaden participation among groups that are traditionally underrepresented in these fields. 

The topics of the conference include random walks and boundaries, ergodic-theoretic methods, and groups of dynamical origins. The conference will feature three plenary talks. The first will focus on interactions between geometry and discrete probability with applications to random walks, percolation, and the Ising modeling of statistical mechanics. The second involves applications of the geometry of buildings and group actions on cell complexes with climate scientists, in the implementation of the computer package that is used in climate simulation and weather prediction. The third talk will cover applications of combinatorial curvature to analyze the structure of geometric networks.  Probabilistic properties of random walks on groups reveal a close relationship between geometric and algebraic properties. This relationship has been made explicit for the class of hyperbolic groups via the equivalence of the Martin and Gromov boundaries. Exploring this relationship outside the class of hyperbolic groups has resulted in the construction of new notions of boundaries that will be discussed at this conference. Ergodic-theoretic notions and theorems from the classical setting of manifolds have just begun to be understood for more general spaces and groups. Much work remains in relating ergodic-theoretic, group-theoretic, and geometric invariants even in the hyperbolic case.  Finally, groups of dynamical origin have recently provided new examples of infinite groups that settle long-standing open problems in the area. Those examples as well as future directions for study will be discussed at the conference as well. The event webpage is at  https://sites.google.com/view/gagta2023.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Delaram Kahrobaei and Arman Darbinyan began a new collaboration. They are working on a paper from that collaboration.

 

The paper “Uniform first order interpretation of the second order theory of countable groups of homeomorphisms” (Koberda and de la Nuez Gonzalez) resulted from my participation at GAGTA.

 

R\'emi Coulon, Francesco Fournier-Facio, and Clara L\"oh 

discussed an ongoing project on bounded cohomology of 

Tarski monster groups.

 

The paper R. Dougall and R. Sharp, “A non-symmetric Kesten criterion and ration limit theorem for random walks on amenable groups” (IMRN, 2024, 7, 6209-6223) was nearly finished by the time of GAGTA but Remark 1.6 was added as a response to a question by Remi Coulon at the meeting.

 

Jacob Garcia, Elliott Vest and Yulan Qing met for the first time at GAGTA and started a joint project titled “Topological and dynamic properties of the sublinearly Morse boundary and the quasi-redirecting boundary”. The paper is recently finished.

 

One question asked at the open problems session at GAGTA has started a new project participated by Ilya Gekhtman, Yulan Qing and Kasra Rafi and a fourth collaborator who joined later.

 

Attending helped broaden my knowledge about geometric group theory since the university I attended did not have a course at the time which led into my thesis. 

 

I (Ian Leary) met quite a few Geometric Group Theorists for the first time and came away feeling inspired, although I don’t have any particular result I can attribute to attending. 

I learned a lot from all the talks. In particular I enjoyed the talk by James Hyde on the subject of the simple finitely generated groups of homeomorphisms of the real line. I am now in the process of writing a paper about the properties of such groups. I also learned from talking to Clara Loh during the social breaks about her book on l2 Betti numbers of groups.  [Pawel Fedorynski]

 

Tom Hutchcroft: among many other interesting and insightful conversations I had at the conference, Nicolas Matte Bon pointed out to me a large class of additional examples to which a theorem I presented applied to. Minghao Pan and I are currently very close to putting the paper online, and I will write something in the acknowledgements crediting the conference.

 

I met Ecaterina Sava-Hust for the first time at GAGTA.  We have been meeting sporadically since.  Hopefully at some point this will materialize into a research project. 

Also, I had some very interesting research discussions with Tom Hutchcroft, and with Corentin Bodart.  I am still in touch with both of them, and hopefully this can also turn into future projects.

 

Elliott, Yulan, and I are pleased to let you know that we've just submitted a paper to the arxiv titled "Topological and Dynamic Properties of the Sublinearly Morse Boundary and the Quasi-Redirecting Boundary". We first met as a group to discuss this project at GAGTA, and we've listed GAGTA in the acknowledgements section for bringing us together to make this project happen. I would also like to share that being able to present a poster at the conference was an incredible help to me, and I was very glad that I was able to present my current work as a graduate student.

 

I personally had very positive interactions while there, including getting to know Dr. Collin Bleak and learning about the Rational Group and its connections to automata.

I also greatly enjoyed meeting Drs. Cashen and Fernós and learning of their general mathematical philosophies and techniques. I can't thank you enough for having given me such a wonderful opportunity.

 

Henry Bradford: A conversation with Nicolas Matte Bon following my short talk helped me and my collaborators (Jakob Schneider and Andreas Thom) add a result (Theorem 1.10) to our paper “On the length of non-solutions to equations with constants in some linear groups” (since published in the Bulletin of the LMS). The discussion with Nicolas inspired me to think more about applications of topological dynamics to word-maps, and a further paper on this subject is in the works. I also had an extremely useful discussion with Tianyi Zheng about invariant random subgroups, which contributed to proving a result about permutation stability (to appear on arXiv later this year). 

 

Yash Lodha: In my work with James Hyde at the conference we constructed a new family of uniformly simple finitely presented and infinite groups with some surprising properties. We are currently writing the paper, and expect it to be on the arxiv by the end of September this year.

 

Donggyun Seo: I am currently working on a project focused on the surface representations of a free group. The conversations at GAGTA have since expanded its scope.


Last Modified: 09/04/2024
Modified by: Kim E Ruane
